Award.AwardTitle: Research Initiation Award: Effects of atomic-scale disorder on carrier transport in photovoltaic cells under concentrated sunlight

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
Research Initiation Awards provide support for junior and mid-career faculty at Historically Black Colleges and Universities who are building new research programs or redirecting and rebuilding existing research programs. It is expected that the award helps to further the faculty member's research capability and effectiveness, improves research and teaching at his home institution, and involves undergraduate students in research experiences. The award to Lincoln University, Pennsylvania, has potential broader impact in a number of areas. The goal of the project is to study carrier transport in polycrystalline silicon solar cells and in solar cells that include low-dimensional quantum dot structures under high incident optical power densities. The research is expected to be an integral part in the development of a new Engineering Science program at the university and will be linked to undergraduate students' coursework and capstone research.

The carrier transport in disordered semiconductors, in particular in silicon, when the optical illumination is varied, is not understood well, compared to that in monocrystalline materials. This project proposes a new approach to theoretical modeling of solar cells made of polycrystalline silicone and quantum dot solar cells, which will combine existing theories of charge carrier dynamics near grain boundaries with a computational method that is based on both semiclassical Boltzmann and quantum mechanical wavepacket Monte Carlo methods. The project will incorporate experimental data about the material microstructure into the models and then compare the experimental and the computational characterization results. The expected application is a better design of inexpensive photovoltaic systems that use concentrated sunlight.

POR.DRECONTENT:
One of the recent trends in photovoltaics is to operate solar panels under concentrated sunlight in order to reduce the required solar panel dimensions.  At the same time, photovoltaic conversion efficiency of solar cells is a key parameter that engineers try to maximize.  In all PV cells some fraction of the charges generated in a semiconductor due to absorption of photons is lost to carrier recombination.  Electronic transport properties of multicrystalline silicon (mc-Si), main semiconductor material used in solar cell manufacturing today, vary within a wide range.

In this project, the PI and his students used experimental characterization to study charge carrier transport in mc-Si under pulsed illumination reaching up to 50 Suns, as well as a computational and theoretical modeling in order to explain the effects of excess carrier density on the recombination rates in mc-Si samples. Experimental approaches included transient photoconductance decay/quasi-steady state transient photoconductance (TPC/QSSPC) and infrared band-to-band photoluminescence imaging (IR PL). The TPC experiments were carried out using a Sinton WCT-120 lifetime tester that PI received through the supplemental funding for this grant. The IR PL measurements were done at UIUC Talbot Lab with the assistance of a graduate student from the research mentor’s group.

Semiclassical carrier transport models including Shockley-Read-Hall and Auger recombination were applied on the scale of a PV cell to study how various types of point defects (e.g., interstitial Fe and FeB pairs formed in p-type mc-Si), as well as grain boundaries affect the carrier transport in mc-Si under various levels of incident light intensity.

Unlike traditional approaches focusing on carrier diffusion lengths and related approximate solutions, the models developed by the PI use partial differential transport equations solved numerically on the scale of a PV cell. The I-V curves that reflect the influence of defect recombination are readily computed for various incident light intensities, allowing the quantification of the relative contributions of various recombination processes.

As a result of this project, the PI found that at moderately concentrated sunlight (1-10 Suns), the most significant contributor to the carrier losses is the recombination at impurities that constitute interstitials and other point defects, while the grain boundary recombination is less significant. Higher order non-radiative recombination processes, such as Auger, are unlikely to occur until very high light concentration factors (in the hundreds and the thousands), unless a solar cell region is heavily doped, causing Coulomb enhancement of the high-order non-radiative recombination processes.

Depending on the type of an impurity, the apparent minority carrier lifetimes as functions of illuminating intensity can vary in a wide range. The PI found that results of IR PL performed at relatively low excitation intensity (~1 Sun) correlate well with the apparent lifetimes from TPC for the same intensity, however, it does not provide a meaningful estimate of what the high-injection lifetime for the same sample would be.

The total of eight undergraduate African American students worked on the project. Several of them presented their work at conferences and co-authored IEEE and APS publications. The training that the students received is useful for physics and engineering science majors. Some of the students employed under this grant also studied other STEM disciplines. The student projects ranged from metrology and experiment automation to numerical modeling and image processing. As of August 2018, all students supported, except two, have successfully graduated from Lincoln and are pursuing graduate studies or working full-time.

The Lincoln University’s new Engineering Science program has received several important instruments, including the Sinton WCT-120 lifetime tester, the solar simulator from ABET, Inc., variable DC load from Chroma, Inc., and Newport UV-VIS monochromator and COMSOL Multiphysics software. The equipment has been used in teaching courses such as Sophomore and Junior Physics Labs, Engineering Capstones, Electronics, Electromagnetic Theory. The PI also intends to apply for funding for his prospective collaborative research, tentatively, with other faculty members who specialize in materials characterization and neuroscience.
